TEXT.English: I come in peace to ask for assistance. What do you say?
TEXT.French: Je suis venu en paix vous demander de l'aide. Qu'avez-vous à répondre?
TEXT.German: Ich komme in Frieden und bitte um Unterstützung. Wie lautet Eure Antwort?
TEXT.Italian: Vengo in pace alla ricerca di aiuto. Cosa mi rispondi?
TEXT.Spanish: Vengo en son de paz a pedir ayuda. ¿Qué me decís?
TEXT.Polish: Przybywam w pokoju. Czy pomożesz mi?

TEXT.English: I hold the fate of the [CT_EMPIRE] in my hand. Give me what I demand.
TEXT.French: Je tiens le destin de l'[CT_EMPIRE] dans ma main. Donnez-moi ce que j'exige.
TEXT.German: Ich halte das Schicksal vom [CT_EMPIRE:3] in meinen Händen. Gebt mir, was ich verlange.
TEXT.Italian: Ho nelle mani il destino di [CT_EMPIRE]. Dammi ciò che chiedo.
TEXT.Spanish: Tengo el destino del [CT_EMPIRE] en mis manos. Dadme lo que os exijo.
TEXT.Polish: W moich rękach leży los [CT_EMPIRE]. Daj mi czego się domagam.

TEXT.English: My town folks are in need, can the [CT_EMPIRE] help?
TEXT.French: Ma personnes est dans le besoin, l'[CT_EMPIRE] peut-il nous aider?
TEXT.German: Mein Stamm ist in Not, kann uns das [CT_EMPIRE:2] helfen?
TEXT.Italian: I miei concittadini hanno bisogno di aiuto, potete aiutarci?
TEXT.Polish: Mieszkańcy mojego imperium potrzebują Twojej pomocy. Pomożesz?

TEXT.English: Hello. I am [OUR_NAME], Marshall of [OUR_CIV_ADJ] township. I consider you a friend. It is in your best interest that I never change that opinion.
TEXT.Polish: Witam. Jestem [OUR_NAME], Szeryf [OUR_CIV_ADJ]. Traktuję Cię jak przyjaciela. W Twoim interesie leży nie zmieniać tego statusu.

TEXT.English: It is good to hear from the [CT_EMPIRE]. To what do I owe this honor?
TEXT.French: Quel plaisir d'avoir de vos nouvelles! Que me vaut cet honneur?
TEXT.German: Es ist gut, etwas vom [CT_EMPIRE:3] zu hören. Womit haben wir diese Ehre verdient?
TEXT.Italian: È bello avere notizie da [CT_EMPIRE]. A cosa debbo quest'onore?
TEXT.Spanish: Es un placer oír al [CT_EMPIRE]. ¿A qué debo este honor?
TEXT.Polish: Dobrze usłyszeć znajomy głos z CT_EMPIRE]. Czym mogę służyć?

TEXT.English: You have started down a path that will lead to your destruction. Feel free to try to explain yourself.
TEXT.French: Vous vous êtes engagé sur la voie qui menera à votre destruction. J'attends vos explications.
TEXT.German: Ihr habt begonnen, einen Pfad zu beschreiten, der zu Eurer Vernichtung führen wird. Wollt Ihr Euch möglicherweise rechtfertigen?
TEXT.Italian: Ti sei avviato lungo un cammino che porterà alla tua distruzione. Prova pure a cercare di spiegarti.
TEXT.Spanish: Habéis hollado una senda que os llevará a la destrucción. Intentad explicaros como queráis.
TEXT.Polish: Wstąpiłeś na ściężkę, która doprowadzi Cię do zguby. Masz coś na usprawiedliwienie?

TEXT.English: You want to talk? It is a little too late for that.
TEXT.French: Vous voulez parler? C'est un peu tard pour ça.
TEXT.German: Ihr wollt reden? Dafür ist es etwas zu spät.
TEXT.Italian: Vuoi parlare? È un po' troppo tardi per farlo.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Ahora queréis hablar? Es un poco tarde para eso.
TEXT.Polish: Chcesz rozmawiać? Niestety jest już na to zbyt późno.

TEXT.English: [H1]Wyatt Berry Stapp Earp[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Deputy Town Marshal[NEWLINE]Lived:[\BOLD] c. March 19, 1848 – January 13, 1929[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]was a gambler, Pima County Deputy Sheriff, and Deputy Town Marshal in Tombstone, Arizona, and took part in the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral during which lawmen killed three outlaw Cowboys. To Wyatt's displeasure, the 30-second gunfight defined the rest of his life. He is often regarded as the central figure in the shootout in Tombstone, although his brother Virgil was Tombstone City Marshal and Deputy U.S. Marshal that day, and had far more experience as a sheriff, constable, and marshal and in combat.[PARAGRAPH:1]Earp was at different times in his life a city policeman, county sheriff, a teamster, buffalo hunter, bouncer, saloon-keeper, gambler, brothel owner, pimp, miner, and a boxing referee. Earp spent his early life in Iowa. His first wife Urilla Sutherland Earp died while pregnant less than a year after they married. Within the next two years he was arrested, sued twice, escaped from jail, then was arrested three more times for "keeping and being found in a house of ill-fame". He landed in the cattle boomtown of Wichita, Kansas where he became a deputy city marshal for one year and developed a solid reputation as a lawman. In 1876 he followed his brother James to Dodge City, Kansas where he became an assistant city marshal. In winter 1878, he went to Texas to gamble where he met John Henry "Doc" Holliday whom Earp credited with saving his life.[PARAGRAPH:1]Earp moved constantly throughout most of his life from one boomtown to another. He left Dodge City in 1879 and with his brothers James and Virgil, moved to Tombstone, Arizona where a huge silver boom was underway. The Earps bought an interest in the Vizina mine and some water rights. There, the Earps clashed with a loose federation of outlaw cowboys. Wyatt, Virgil, and their younger brother Morgan held various law enforcement positions that put them in conflict with Tom and Frank McLaury, and Ike and Billy Clanton, who threatened to kill the Earps. The conflict escalated over the next year, culminating on October 26, 1881 in the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, during which the Earps and Holliday killed three of the Cowboys. In the next five months, Virgil was ambushed and maimed and Morgan was assassinated. Pursuing a vendetta, Wyatt, his brother Warren, Holliday, and others formed a federal posse which killed three of the Cowboys they thought responsible. Unlike his lawmen brothers Virgil and James, Wyatt was never wounded in the few gunfights he took part in, which only added to his mystique after his death.[PARAGRAPH:1]After leaving Tombstone, Earp and his third wife Josephine Earp moved from one boomtown to another, starting in Eagle City, Idaho; followed by San Diego, California; Nome, Alaska; Tonopah, Nevada; and finally Vidal, California. An extremely flattering, largely fictionalized, best-selling biography published after his death created his reputation as a fearless lawman. As a result of the book, Wyatt Earp has been the subject of and model for a large number of films, TV shows, biographies and works of fiction that have increased his mystique. Earp's modern-day reputation is that of the Old West's "toughest and deadliest gunman of his day". Until the book was published, Earp had a dubious reputation as a minor figure in Western history. Wyatt Earp was born in Monmouth in Warren County in western Illinois, on March 19, 1848, to widower Nicholas Porter Earp and Virginia Ann Cooksey. From his father's first marriage, Wyatt had an elder half-brother, Newton, and a half-sister Mariah Ann, who died at the age of ten months. Wyatt was named after his father's commanding officer in the Mexican-American War, Captain Wyatt Berry Stapp, of the 2nd Company Illinois Mounted Volunteers. In March 1849, the Earps left Monmouth for California but settled in Iowa. Their new farm consisted of 160 acres (0.65 km2), 7 miles (11 km) northeast of Pella, Iowa. The family left and returned to Pella when the American Civil War began. Newton, James, and Virgil joined the Union Army on November 11, 1861. While his father was busy recruiting and drilling local companies, Wyatt, along with his two younger brothers, Morgan and Warren, were left in charge of tending 80-acre (32 ha) corn crop. Only thirteen years old, Wyatt was too young to enlist, but he tried on several occasions to run away and join the army. Each time his father found him and brought him home. James was severely wounded in Fredericktown, Missouri, and returned home in summer 1863. Newton and Virgil fought several battles in the east and later followed the family to California.
TEXT.Polish: [H1]Wyatt Berry Stapp Earp[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zastępca Szeryfa[NEWLINE]Żył:[\BOLD] Marzec 19, 1848 – Styczeń 13, 1929[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Tło:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Wyatt Berry Stapp Earp (ur. 19 marca 1848 w Monmouth, Illinois; zm. 13 stycznia 1929 w Los Angeles) - farmer, szeryf, karciarz, właściciel salonu, poszukiwacz złota, łowca bizonów, jeden z najsłynniejszych na Dzikim Zachodzie rewolwerowców oraz stróżów prawa, szeryf miasteczka Tombstone. Zasłynął szczególnie ze strzelaniny w O.K. Corral, w której brali również udział Doc Holliday oraz bracia Wyatta, Virgil i Morgan. Wyatt Earp stał się bohaterem licznych filmów (np. z 1994 roku), biografii oraz powieści. Swoją drogę życiową opowiedział dopiero w wieku 80 lat pisarzowi Stuartowi N. Lake, który następnie napisał książkę pt. "Wyatt Earp, Frontier-Marshal", która uczyniła z Earpa legendę, trwającą aż do dziś.
